block.p: Suicide Bombers Kill 36 At Iraqi Police Academy Powerful explosions from two suicide bombs ripped through the capital's main police academy, killing at least 36 police officers and wounding 72 others, an Interior Ministry official and the American military said.

Vice President Dick Cheney, appearing before more than 2,000 troops in northern New York, said the administration has ''a comprehensive strategy for victory'' in Iraq and is making progress in training Iraqi troops.

Rice Criticized in Europe Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice was pelted with criticism about covert prisons and a mistaken, secret arrest, as she grappled with what has become an incendiary issue in Europe.

German Claims Abuse by U.S. A German citizen who says he was abducted in 2003, beaten and taken to Afghanistan by American agents in what was apparently a case of mistaken identity, filed suit in federal court against George J. Tenet, the former C.I.A. director, and three companies suspected of being involved in secret C.I.A. flights.

U.N. Report on Syria Hits Snag Setbacks in the United Nations investigation into the assassination of a former Lebanese prime minister have raised questions about evidence supporting the charge that Syria was responsible for the assassination, according to Western diplomats based in Syria.

115 Die in Iran Air Crash A military plane loaded with Iranian journalists crashed into an apartment building as the pilot tried an emergency landing after developing engine trouble. At least 115 people died, Iranian authorities said.
U.N. Fires Elections Director The United Nations fired Carina Perelli, the director of its highly regarded elections services office on accusations of sexual harassment and abuse of authority.
Israel Arrests 15 in Bombing Israeli security forces, in response to a suicide bombing on Monday that killed five Israelis, arrested 15 suspected Palestinian militants in overnight raids.

China Contests Torture Claims China contested the conclusions of a United Nations envoy and denied that torture was widespread in the country, asking the envoy to revise his views before making a final report on his two-week visit.

Britain's New Opposition Leader Britain's opposition Conservatives chose David Cameron, a 39-year-old product of some of Britain's elite places of learning, as their new leader and likely candidate for prime minister in the next elections.

South Africa Arrests Ex-Official Jacob G. Zuma, the charismatic leader whose dismissal as deputy president last June has unleashed a power struggle in South African politics, was arrested and charged with raping a family friend.

Terror Suspects Not Guilty, A Jury in Florida Decides In a major defeat for federal law enforcement officials, a jury in Florida failed to return guilty verdicts on any of 51 criminal counts against a former Florida professor and three co-defendants accused of operating a North American front for Palestinian terrorists.

Court Hears Case on Recruiting In a Supreme Court showdown, the military argued that it should have access to law schools on the same basis as other potential employers, although gay law students need not apply. The law schools promise that only those employers who pledge not to discriminate are welcome.
In No Rush to Push DeLay Out Senior House Republicans said they saw no need to rush party leadership elections to replace Representative Tom DeLay while he contests criminal charges in Texas.

U.S. Agrees to Build Plant The Bush administration, under pressure from other industrialized countries at talks on global warming in Montreal, announced that it had signed an agreement with a coalition of energy companies to build a prototype coal-burning power plant with no emissions.

More Time to Mend Ozone Hole The layer of ozone in the earth's atmosphere, which protects life from harmful ultraviolet radiation but has been damaged by artificial chemicals, may take a decade or two longer to recover than previously thought, scientists reported.

Stem Cell Error Called Minor An error in an article about an advance in stem cell research arose because the authors supplied the wrong set of replacement photographs and not because of anything that would undermine the article's conclusions, the editors of Science, the journal that published the article, said.

Thousands Bid Farewell To Slain Officer in Brooklyn An estimated 20,000 police officers turned a Brooklyn neighborhood into an ocean of blue in a tribute to Dillon Stewart, a New York police officer who was the first to die in the line of duty this year.
4 Dead in Queens Fire Four people, three of them young children, were killed in Elmhurst, Queens, when a fire tore through the cellar where they lived, Fire Department officials said.

New Issue in M.T.A. Talks The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which has already angered the transit workers union over its over its demand for cheaper pensions for new employees, made a bold proposal just 10 days before the contract expires: having subway conductors walk through train cars instead of staying in their booths.

Pressure Mounts to Rebuild State, city and Port Authority officials are increasing pressure on Larry A. Silverstein, the developer who controls the World Trade Center site, to relinquish at least a portion of the 16-acre property so that the rebuilding effort can proceed more quickly.
Federik Jacques Philips The former president of the Dutch electronics giant that bears his family's name, he was 100.

New Project for Gibson Mel Gibson, whose ''Passion of the Christ'' was assailed by some critics as anti-Semitic -- and whose father has been on record as a Holocaust denier -- has a new project under way: a nonfiction mini- series for television about the Holocaust, to be developed for ABC.

The Battle for Guidant Johnson & Johnson, responding to Boston Scientific's unexpected $25 billion bid for Guidant on Monday, asserted that the $21.5 billion merger agreement it had reached with Guidant on Nov. 15 represented ''full and fair value.''

Gap's Woes Are Growing Gap is struggling. Sales are slumping, a string of executives have left in recent months and Wall Street analysts are openly questioning whether the company's leadership is up to the job.
Big Board Deal Approved Members of the New York Stock Exchange voted to approve a merger with Archipelago Holdings, an all-electronic exchange.
Editorials: Secretary Rice's rendition; Senator Clinton, in pander mode; pushing the envelope.
